oai_dc:dc.dc:title: David Arnold interview
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Arnold, David
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: David Arnold was AUC's tenth president, serving from 2003 to 2010. He recalls his early career in government service in the US, and his work at the Ford Foundation and International Institute of Education. Arnold tells of how he became president of AUC, including the impact of his association with the Ford Foundation's John Gerhart, his predecessor as the university's president. The construction of AUC's new campus and move from downtown Cairo is covered, including the figures involved, the challenges of the project, and its impact on the university. Arnold describes the travel and other fundraising efforts in which he and trustees, administrators, his wife Sherry and others engaged, and outlines AUC's financial situation and administrative changes in the years of his presidency. Arnold provides an overview of academic matters like the contribution of AUC's provosts and the emergence of new schools and centers. Faculty issues are addressed as are developments in the area of student affairs, such as the LEAD scholarship program and impact of international students. Other topics covered include the expression of religion and politics on campus, relations with the Egyptian government, and the emergence of competing private universities. He closes with a discussion of his departure from the presidency of AUC.
